1974-1980s, 2012 Roberta Wood (1949-) has served as Secretary Treasurer of the Communist Party since 2007 and is a lifelong rank and file union activist. The Roberta Wood Collection consists of materials collected by Wood over the course of her decades of labor and political activism.
Conditions Governing Access
Materials are open without restrictions.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Donated by Roberta Wood in 2012; additional materials were donated in 2014. The accession number related to these gifts is 2012.082.
Arrangement
Materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor.
Biographical Note
Roberta Wood (1949-) has served as Secretary Treasurer of the Communist Party since 2007. A lifelong rank and file union activist, Roberta co-founded the steelworker women's caucus in the in the Chicago/Gary district of the Steelworkers union. In 1976 she was elected the first female member of USWA Local 65's Executive Board. Following the closing of US Steel's South Works mill, Roberta worked until retirement as an electrical instrumentation mechanic in a municipal sewage treament facility. She served several years as labor editor of the People's Weekly World, forerunner to the People's World.
Source: http://www.cpusa.org/new-biography-2

Processing Information
Materials have been rehoused into archival quality folders and slide protectors. Folder titles added by the archivist are indicated with square brackets.

Communist Party of the United States of America Records (TAM 132)
Scope and Content Note
The Roberta Wood Collection consists of materials collected by Wood over the course of her decades of labor and political activism. The collection is mostly comprised of financial statements, publicity, and planning materials from the Labor Education Fund's tribute for Florence Reece and the Ernesto De Maio Tribute Committee's tribute for Ernie De Maio, both in the 1970s. The collection also contains an oral history with Roberta Wood conducted in 2012 and biographies of numerous leaders in the labor, civil rights, and peace movements, collected for the Unity Center's (likely unpublished) Honor Roll and Golden Book of the Working Class. There are also notes and slides from the World Assembly of Builders of Peace Meeting in Warsaw, Poland in 1977.
Conditions Governing Use
Copyright (or related rights to publicity and privacy) for materials in this collection, created by Roberta Wood, was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder.
